Description: Terracotta figure of dog. Handmade dog in primitive style. Nose, left rear leg, and one ear missing. Red stripe over front and legs and back and legs. Pale white-buff fabric with fine black inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The letters AP and P, followed by the object's number, appear on many Boston objects, but do not seem to correspond to provenance information. Dogs are rarely depicted in Cypriot art until the 6th century BC, when they become very common in coroplastic art (Karageorghis 1996, 42). Closest parallels from Cyprus and specifically at Salamis-Cellarka are dated to the 6th century BC and the Cypro-Archaic II period (Karageorghis 1996, 42-5, pls 25.9,11, 26.4 Types O10-O11 & O16). Karageorghis, V. 1996. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. VI. The Cypro-Archaic Period monsters, animals and miscellanea. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.087) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5832 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
